title: Notes on Pointwise Finite-Dimensional $2$-Parameter Persistence Modules

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper, we study pointwise finite-dimensional (p.f.d.) 2-parameter persistence modules where each module admits a finite convex isotopy subdivision. We show that a p.f.d. 2-parameter persistence module $M$ (with a finite convex isotopy subdivision) is isomorphic to a 2-parameter persistence module $N$ where the restriction of $N$ to each chamber of the parameter space $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ is a constant functor. Moreover, we show that the convex isotopy subdivision of $M$ induces a finite encoding of $M$. Finally, we prove that every indecomposable thin 2-parameter persistence module is isomorphic to a polytope module.


Keywords: 2-parameter persistence module, representation over poset
MSC Classification: 55N31

## Contents

1 Introduction 2
2 Preliminaries: Persistence Modules Over Posets 3
3 2-Parameter p.f.d. Persistence Modules with Convex Isotopy Subdivisions 4

# 1 Introduction 

Persistent homology is a mathematical concept widely applied to analyze the topological features of data clouds. Let $\mathbb{F}$ be a field and $(P, \leq)$ be the set $P$ with a partial order. A persistence module over $(P, \leq)$ is a family of $\mathbb{F}$-vector spaces $\{M i \mid i \in P\}$ and a doubly-indexed family of linear maps $\{M(i \leq j): M i \rightarrow M j \mid i \leq j\}$ such that $M(j \leq k) \circ M(i \leq j)=M(i \leq k)$ for any $i \leq j \leq k$ in $P$ and $M(i \leq i)=\operatorname{id}_{M i}$ for all $i \in P$. Equivalently, $M$ can be viewed as a functor $M:(P, \leq) \rightarrow$ Vect $_{\mathbb{F}}$. We use $\mathbf{V e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(P, \leq)}$ to denote the category of persistence modules over $(P, \leq)$. A persistence module $M$ is called pointwise finite-dimensional (p.f.d.) when $M i$ is a finitedimensional vector space for all $i \in P$, and we denote the full subcategory of Vect $_{\mathbb{F}}$ consisting of all finite-dimensional vector spaces over $\mathbb{F}$ as vect $_{\mathbb{F}}$. In particular, when $(P, \leq)=\left(\mathbb{R}, \leq\right)^{n}$ with the product order ${ }^{1}$, the objects of $\mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(R, \leq)^{n}}$ are called n-parameter p.f.d. persistence modules.

Every $n$-parameter p.f.d. persistence module $M$ is equivalent to a $\mathbb{R}^{n}$-graded module over $\mathbb{F}[0,+\infty)^{n}$ [1]. When $n=1$, an algebraic invariant (called barcode) of $M$ can be obtained by assigning an interval to each direct summand of $M$. Botnan and Crawley-Boevey prove that the barcode is well-defined [2]. Barcode can be viewed as the persistence analog of the Betti number [3].

When $n \geq 2$, there is no structure theorem available for $\mathbb{R}^{n}$-graded modules over $\mathbb{F}[0,+\infty)^{n}$. Therefore, there is no algebraic characterization of multiparameter p.f.d. persistence modules that is analogous to the barcodes of the 1-parameter p.f.d. persistence modules. Moreover, the indecomposable submodules of a multiparameter p.f.d. persistence module can be very complicated. For example, Buchet and Escolar show that any $n$-parameter persistence module can be embedded as a slice of an indecomposable $(n+1)$-parameter persistence module [4] [5].

In this paper, we first present some results about the 2-parameter p.f.d. persistence modules that admit a finite convex isotopy subdivision (Definition 1). Moreover, we present a result regarding the indecomposable thin 2-parameter persistence modules.

## Main Results

Here are the main results of this paper:
Theorem 1. Given $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(R, \leq)^{2}}$. Assume there exists a finite convex isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$. Then $M \cong N$, where $N:(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2} \rightarrow$ vect $_{\mathbb{F}}$ is defined as follows:

- For every chamber $J, N j=\lim _{I} M$ for all $j \in J$;

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ In other words, $\left(a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n}\right) \leq\left(b_{1}, \ldots, b_{n}\right) \in(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{n}$ if and only if $a_{i} \leq b_{i}$ for all $i=1, \ldots, n$.

- For all $j_{1} \leq j_{2}$, let $J_{1}$ be the chamber containing $j_{1}$, and $J_{2}$ be the chamber containing $j_{2}$. Then $N\left(j_{1} \leq j_{2}\right): N j_{1} \rightarrow N j_{2}$ is

$$
N\left(j_{1} \leq j_{2}\right)= \begin{cases}\text { id }_{\lim _{j} M}, & \text { if } J:=J_{1}=J_{2} \\ \phi_{J_{1} J_{2}}, & \text { else }\end{cases}
$$

The construction of linear transformation $\phi_{J_{1} J_{2}}$ is provided in Proposition 6.
Because the functor category $\mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$ is a Krull-Schmidt category [2], it follows that to determine the indecomposable direct summands of $M$, it suffices to find the indecomposable direct summands of $N$.
Theorem 2. Given $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$. Assume there exists a finite convex isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$, and let $(P, \leq)$ be the poset of chambers. Then $M \cong \tilde{N} \circ \mathcal{F}_{M}$, where $\tilde{N}:(P, \leq) \rightarrow \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}$ is defined as follows:

- Given $p \in P, \tilde{N}_{p}=\lim _{J_{p}} M \cong$ Mi for all $i \in J_{p}$;
- For all $p \leq q \in P$,

$$
\tilde{N}(p \leq q)= \begin{cases}\text { id }_{\lim _{j_{p}} M}, & \text { if } p=q \\ \phi_{J_{p} J_{q}}, & \text { else }\end{cases}
$$

where $\phi_{J_{p} J_{q}}$ is the canonical linear transformation defined in Proposition 6.
Therefore, any finite convex isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$ is also a constant subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$ and a finite encoding of $M$.

Next, we study thin 2-parameter persistence modules. It is well-known that interval modules, as objects of $\mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(P, \leq)}$, are indecomposable. In particular, when $(P, \leq)=(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$, polytope modules are indecomposable. However, the converse of this statement does not hold in general. By imposing additional assumptions, the converse may be true up to isomorphism. For example, it is known that every thin indecomposable persistence module on a finite 2-dimensional grid is isomorphic to an interval module [6]. In this paper, we extend this result to indecomposable thin persistence modules over $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ :
Theorem 3. Every indecomposable thin persistence module $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$ is isomorphic to a polytope module.

Theorem 2 and Theorem 3 may fail when $M$ has more than two parameters. See Example 3.

# 2 Preliminaries: Persistence Modules Over Posets 

Let $(P, \leq)$ be a poset. A subset $\mathbf{I}$ of $P$ is called convex if $i, k \in \mathbf{I}$ implies $j \in \mathbf{I}$ for any $i \leq j \leq k$ in $P$, and is called connected if for all $a, b \in \mathbf{I}$, there exists $x_{0}:=$ $a, x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n-1}, x_{n}:=b$ in P such that $x_{i}$ and $x_{i+1}$ are comparable for all $i=0, \ldots, n-$ 1. The set $\mathbf{I}$ is called an interval of $(P, \leq)$ if $\mathbf{I}$ is connected and convex.

Assume $(P, \leq)=(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ and let $p: a-x_{1}-x_{2}-\cdots-x_{n}-b$ be a zigzag path in $J \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{2}$, where - is $\leq$ or $\geq . p$ is called a staircase is $p$ consists only of horizontal and

vertical arrows in $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$. Moreover, $p$ is called a reduced staircase if it contains no two consecutive horizontal or vertical arrows. When $J \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{2}$ is convex (as a poset), there exists a reduced staircase for every zigzag path $p$ in $J$. Since $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ is a thin category, we may assume $p$ is a reduced staircase.

Let $(P, \leq)$ be a poset and $\mathbf{I} \subseteq(P, \leq)$ is an interval. Define the interval module $\mathbb{F} \mathbf{I}$ as

$$
\mathbb{F} \mathbf{I} i= \begin{cases}\mathbb{F}, & \text { if } i \in \mathbf{I} \\ 0, & \text { if } i \notin \mathbf{I}\end{cases} \quad \text { and } \quad \operatorname{Hom}(\mathbb{F} \mathbf{I} i, \mathbb{F} \mathbf{I} j)= \begin{cases}\left\{\mathrm{id}_{\mathbb{F}}\right\}, & \text { if } i \leq j \in \mathbf{I} \\ 0, & \text { else }\end{cases}
$$

When $(P, \leq)=(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{n}$ and $n \geq 2$, we call $\mathbb{F} \mathbf{I}$ the polytope module over $\mathbf{I}$.
Let $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbf{F}}^{(P, \leq)}: M$ is decomposable if there exists non-trivial subrepresentations $N$ and $N^{\prime}$ such that $M i \cong N i \oplus N^{\prime} i$ for all $i \in P$. We say $M$ is indecomposable if it is not decomposable. $M$ is a thin representation if $\operatorname{dim}(M i)=0$ or 1 for all $i \in P$.

The following lemma about interval modules is well-known.
Lemma 1. Interval modules are thin and indecomposable.
Proof. Let $M$ be an interval module. The support of $M$ is an interval of $(P, \leq)$. Consider the endomorphism ring of $M$. We want to show $\operatorname{End}(M) \cong \mathbb{F}$. Let $f \in \operatorname{End}(M)$. Note that for every $p \in(P, \leq), f_{p}: \mathbb{F} \rightarrow \mathbb{F}$ is a linear transformation, hence $f_{p}(x)=c_{f} \cdot x$ for some $c_{f} \in \mathbb{F}$. Let $p^{\prime}$ be a point in the support of $M$. Note that there exists a zigzag path from $p$ to $p^{\prime}$ because the support of $M$ is an interval. Since $f$ is a morphism between two representations and $M$ is a polytope module, we must have $f_{q}(x)=c_{f} \cdot x$. Define $\Phi: \operatorname{End}(M) \rightarrow \mathbb{F}$ by $\Phi(f)=c_{f}$ for each $f \in \operatorname{End}(M)$. It is clear that $\Phi$ is bijective, so we only need to show that $\Phi$ is a ring homomorphism. Note that $\Phi(f+g)=c_{f}+c_{g}=\Phi(f)+\Phi(g)$ and $\Phi(f \circ g)=c_{f} \cdot g=\Phi(f) \Phi(g)$, hence $\Phi$ is a ring homomorphism.

Let $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbf{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$. A constant subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$ [7] is a partition of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ into constant regions such that for each constant region $I$ there is a single vector space $M_{I}$ with $M_{I} \rightarrow M_{i}$ for all $i \in I$ that has no monodromy: if J is another constant region, then all comparable pairs $i \leq j$ with $i \in I$ and $j \in J$ induce the same composite homomorphism $M_{I} \rightarrow M_{J}$.

Fix a poset $(Q, \leq)$. An encoding [7] of a $Q$-module $M$ by a poset $(P, \leq)$ is a poset morphism $\pi:(Q, \leq) \rightarrow(P, \leq)$ together with a $P$-module $H$ such that $M \cong \pi^{+} H$, the pullback of $H$ along $\pi$, which is naturally a $Q$-module. The encoding is finite if $(P, \leq)$ is finite (here $\operatorname{dim}\left(H_{p}\right)$ is also finite for all $p \in(P, \leq)$ since $M$ is p.f.d.).

# 3 2-Parameter p.f.d. Persistence Modules with Convex Isotopy Subdivisions 

Definition 1 (Isotopy Subdivision). Let $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbf{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$. An isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$ is a partition of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ into connected subsets (called chambers) such that $M(a \leq b)$ is an isomorphism provided that $a \leq b$ are contained in the same chamber. An isotopy subdivision is finite if the number of chambers in the partition is finite.

Moreover, we call the partition a convex isotopy subdivision if every chamber in the isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ is convex.

Given $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{R}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$. Assume there exists a finite convex isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$. In this section, we show that there exists $N \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{R}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$ where $N(i \leq j)=i d$ for all $i$ and $j$ in a chamber such that $M \cong N$. In particular, Proposition 6 shows that every finite convex isotopy subdivision of $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{R}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$ is a finite constant subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$.
Definition 2. Let $J \subseteq(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ be a connected poset and $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{R}}^{j}$ such that $M(i \leq j)$ is an isomorphism for all $i \leq j \in J$. For each comparable pair $i$ and $j$ in $J$, define

$$
\hat{M}(i, j)= \begin{cases}M(i \leq j), & \text { if } i \leq j \\ M(j \leq i)^{-1}, & \text { if } j \leq i\end{cases}
$$

An arrow $i-j$ is called a good arrow $(G)$ if $\hat{M}(i, j)=M(i \leq j)$ and is called a bad arrow $(B)$ if $M(i, j)=M(j \leq i)^{-1}$, where - means $\leq$ or $\geq$. Given $a, b \in J$, let $p$ : $a-x_{1}-x_{2}-\cdots-x_{n}-b$ be a zigzag path in $J$, define

$$
M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b\right)=\hat{M}\left(x_{n}, b\right) \circ \hat{M}\left(x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right) \circ \cdots \hat{M}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \circ \hat{M}\left(a, x_{1}\right)
$$

Lemma 2. Let $J \subseteq(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ be a connected and convex poset and $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{R}}^{j}$ such that $M(i \leq j)$ is an isomorphism for all $i \leq j \in J$. Then for any $a \leq b \in J$ and any zigzag path $p: a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{n}-b, M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b\right)=M(a \leq b)$.
Proof. Since $J$ is convex, we may assume $p: a-x_{1}-x_{2}-\cdots-x_{n}-b$ is a reduced staircase. Induction on the length of $p$ (denoted by $l(p)$ ). When $l(p)=1, M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b\right)=$ $M(a \leq b)$ because $J$ is thin.

When $l(p)=2$, there exists $x_{1} \in J$ such that $p: a-x_{1}-b$. If $a \leq x_{1} \leq b$, then $M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b\right)=M(a \leq b)$ because $J$ is thin. If $a \geq x_{1} \geq b$, then $a=x_{1}=b$ and $M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b\right)=$ id $_{M a}=M(a \leq b)$. If $a \leq x_{1} \geq b$, then $M\left(a \leq x_{1}\right)=M\left(b \leq x_{1}\right) \circ M(a \leq b)$. Hence $M(a \leq b)=M\left(b \leq x_{1}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a \leq x_{1}\right)=M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b\right)$. Similarly, if $a \geq x_{1} \leq b$, then $M\left(x_{1} \leq b\right)=M(a \leq b) \circ M\left(x_{1} \leq a\right)$. Hence $M(a \leq b)=M\left(x_{1} \leq b\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \leq\right.$ a) ${ }^{-1}=M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b\right)$.

Assume the statement is true for all zigzag paths of length less or equal to $N$. Let $p: a-x_{1}-x_{2}-\cdots-x_{N}-b$ be a zigzag path from $a$ to $b$ of length $N+1$. If $p$ has a self-intersection $c$, add a new vertex $c$ to $p$. Then we obtain a new path $\tilde{p}$. There are 4 possible forms of $\tilde{p}$ :
(1) $a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{i}-c-x_{i+1}--\cdots-x_{j}-c-x_{j+1}-\cdots-x_{N}-b$ for some $i<j$;
(2) $a-c-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{j}-c-x_{j+1}-\cdots-x_{N}-b$ for some $j$;
(3) $a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{i}-c-x_{i+1}-\cdots-x_{N}-c-b$ for some $i$;
(4) $a-c-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{N}-c-b$.

When $p$ is of the form 1,2 , or 3 , then the induction hypothesis implies that $M(c-$ $\cdots-c)=\mathrm{id}_{M c}$ and hence $M(a \leq b)=M(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b)$. When $p$ is of the form 4 , without loss of generality, we may assume $c \leq x_{1}$. The induction hypothesis implies that $M\left(c \leq x_{1}\right)=M\left(c-x_{N}-x_{N-1}-\cdots-x_{1}\right)$. Hence $M\left(c-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{N}-c\right)=\mathrm{id}_{M c}$. Note that $a-c-b$ is a path in $J$ of length 2 , the induction hypothesis implies that $\hat{M}(c, b) \circ \hat{M}(a, c)=M(a \leq b)$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
M(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b) & =\hat{M}(c, b) \circ \hat{M}\left(x_{N}, c\right) \circ \hat{M}\left(x_{N-1}, x_{N}\right) \circ \cdots \hat{M}\left(c, x_{1}\right) \circ \hat{M}(a, c) \\
& =\hat{M}(c, b) \circ \mathrm{id}_{M c} \circ \hat{M}(a, c) \\
& =M(a \leq b)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we assume $p: a-x_{1}-x_{2}-\cdots-x_{N}-b$ does not have self-intersection. Note that $a$ and $b$ are not comparable if $p$ consists of alternating good (G) and bad (B) arrows. Hence, every arrow of $p$ is good, or $p$ contains a subpath of the form: BBG, GBB, BGG, or GGB. When arrows of $p$ are all good arrows, then $M(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b)=M(a \leq$ $b)$ because $J$ is thin. Now we assume $p$ contains a subpath $x_{i-1}-x_{i}-x_{i+1}-x_{i+2}$ of the form BBG. Because $J \subseteq(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$, there exists a bad arrow $c-d$ where (1) $c=x_{i-1}$ and $x_{i+1}<d \leq x_{i+2}$, or (2) $x_{i}<c \leq x_{i-1}$ and $d=x_{i+2}$. Substitute the subpath $x_{i-1}-x_{i}-x_{i+1}-x_{i+2}$ by (1) $c-d-x_{i+2}$ or (2) $x_{i-1}-c-d$, we obtain a new path $q$ of length at most $N$. The induction hypothesis implies that $M(a \stackrel{q}{\sim} b)=M(a \leq b)$ and (1) $M\left(x_{i-1}-x_{i}-x_{i+1}-x_{i+2}\right)=M\left(c-d-x_{i+2}\right)$ or (2) $M\left(x_{i-1}-x_{i}-x_{i+1}-x_{i+2}\right)=$ $M\left(x_{i-1}-c-d\right)$. Therefore, $M(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b)=M(a \leq b)$. A similar argument shows that the statement is true when $p$ contains a subpath of the form GBB, BGG, or GBB.

By induction, we conclude that $M(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b)=M(a \leq b)$ for all zigzag path $p$ in $J$.

Lemma 3. Let $J \subseteq(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ be a connected and convex poset and $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{K}^{j}$ such that $M(i \leq j)$ is an isomorphism for all $i \leq j \in J$. Then for any $a, b \in J, M(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b)$ does not depend on the choice of zigzag path $p$ connecting $a$ and $b$ in $J$.
Proof. For all $a, b \in J$, let $p: a-x_{1}-x_{2}-\cdots-x_{n}-b$ and $q: a-y_{1}-y_{2}-\cdots-$ $y_{m}-b$ be two zigzag paths from $a$ to $b$. The concatenation of $p$ and the inverse ${ }^{2}$ of $q$, denoted by $p * q^{-1}$, is the zigzag path

$$
p * q^{-1}: a-x_{1}-x_{2}-\cdots-x_{n}-b-y_{m}-\cdots-y_{2}-y_{1}-a
$$

Moreover, $M(a \stackrel{p * q^{-1}}{\sim} a)=M(a \stackrel{q}{\sim} b)^{-1} \circ M(a \stackrel{p}{\sim} b)$ because

$$
M(a \stackrel{q}{\sim} b)^{-1}=\hat{M}\left(a, y_{1}\right)^{-1} \circ \hat{M}\left(y_{1}, y_{2}\right)^{-1} \circ \cdots \circ \hat{M}\left(y_{m}, b\right)^{-1}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ The inverse of a zigzag path $q$, denoted by $q^{-1}$, is a zigzag path obtained by reversing the direction of each edge in $q$.

Lemma 2 implies that $M\left(a \stackrel{q}{\rightarrow} b\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\rightarrow} b\right)=\mathrm{id}_{M a}$. Therefore, $M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\rightarrow} b\right)=M\left(a \stackrel{q}{\rightarrow} b\right)$.
Consequently, when the assumptions in Lemma 3 are satisfied, we drop $p$ from the notation $M\left(a \stackrel{p}{\rightarrow} b\right)$ in Definition 2.
Proposition 4. Let $J \subseteq(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ be a connected and convex poset and $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbf{F}}^{J}$ such that $M(i \leq j)$ is an isomorphism for all $i \leq j \in J$. Then $\lim _{J} M \cong M a$ for all $a \in J$.
Proof. Given $a \in J$, let $M a: J \rightarrow \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbf{F}}$ be a constant functor where $M a(i)=M a$ for all $i \in J$ and $M a(i \leq j)=i \mathrm{id}_{M a}$ for all $i \leq j \in J$. Define $\sigma: M a \Rightarrow M$, where $\sigma_{i}:=M(a \rightsquigarrow i)$ for all $i \in J$. (In particular, $\sigma_{a}=i \mathrm{id}_{M a}$.) Lemma 3 implies that $\sigma_{i}$ is well-defined. For any $i \leq j \in J$, by Lemma $3, M(i \leq j) \circ M(a \rightsquigarrow i)=M(a \rightsquigarrow j)$. Hence $\sigma_{j}=M(i \leq j) \circ \sigma_{i}$ for all $i \leq j \in J$. Therefore, $\sigma: M a \Rightarrow M$ is a cone.

Assume there is a cone $\tau: N \Rightarrow M$. Define $\phi: N \rightarrow M a$ by $\phi:=\tau_{a}$. Given $i \in J$, let $a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{n}-i$ be a zigzag path in $J$. Note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_{i} \circ \phi & =M(a \rightsquigarrow i) \circ \tau_{a} \\
& =\hat{M}\left(x_{n}, i\right) \circ \hat{M}\left(x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right) \circ \cdots \circ \hat{M}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \circ \hat{M}\left(a, x_{1}\right) \circ \tau_{a} \\
& =\hat{M}\left(x_{n}, i\right) \circ \hat{M}\left(x_{n-1}, x_{n}\right) \circ \cdots \circ \hat{M}\left(x_{1}, x_{2}\right) \circ \tau_{x_{1}} \\
& \vdots \\
& =\tau_{i}
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, $\phi$ is a morphism from the cone $\tau$ to the cone $\sigma$.
If there exists another morphism $\psi: N \rightarrow M a$ such that $\tau_{i}=\sigma_{i} \circ \psi$ for all $i \in J$, then $\phi: \tau_{a}=\sigma_{a} \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{M a} \circ \psi=\psi$.

In conclusion, $\sigma$ is a limit cone and $\lim _{J} M \cong M a$ for all $a \in J$.
Next, we construct the morphisms between limits.
Lemma 4. Let $a, a^{\prime} \in J_{1}$ and $b, b^{\prime} \in J_{2}$ such that $a \leq b$ and $a^{\prime} \geq b^{\prime}$, where $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$ are convex and connected subsets of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$. Then $J_{1} \cap J_{2} \neq \varnothing$.
Proof. Since $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$ are convex, the statement is true when $a=a^{\prime}$ or $b=b^{\prime}$. Now we assume $a \neq a^{\prime}$ and $b \neq b^{\prime}$. Let $p: a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{n}-a^{\prime}$ be a zigzag path in $J_{1}$ and $q: b-y_{1}-\cdots-y_{m}-b^{\prime}$ be a zigzag path in $J_{2}$. Since $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$ are convex, we may assume $p$ and $q$ are staircases with no two consecutive horizontal or vertical arrows. Induction on $l(p)+l(q)$.

When $l(p)+l(q)=2$, there are 4 cases: (1) $a \leq a^{\prime}$ and $b \leq b^{\prime}$; (2) $a \geq a^{\prime}$ and $b \leq b^{\prime}$; (3) $a \leq a^{\prime}$ and $b \geq b^{\prime}$; (4) $a \geq a^{\prime}$ and $b \geq b^{\prime}$. Since $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$ are convex, the statement is true for cases (1), (2), and (4). For case (3), note that $a, a^{\prime}, b, b^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$, there exists $c \in \mathbb{R}^{2}$ such that $a \leq c \leq a^{\prime}$ and $b^{\prime} \leq c \leq b$. The convexity of $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$ implies that $c \in J_{1} \cap J_{2}$.

Assume the statement is true when the sum of the lengths of two zigzag paths $a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}$ and $b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}$ is less than or equal to $N$. When $l(p)+l(q) \leq N+1$, there are 3 cases: (1) the arrows in $p$ are all good (or all bad, respectively), or the arrows in $q$ are all good (or all bad, respectively); (2) $p$ or $q$ contains a subpath of the form BBG, GBB,

BGG, or GGB; (3) $p$ and $q$ consist of alternating arrows. For case (1), without loss of generality, we may assume all arrows of $p$ are good. We may replace $p$ with path $p^{\prime}: a \rightarrow a^{\prime}$. Note that $l\left(p^{\prime}\right)+l(q) \leq N$, by induction hypothesis, $J_{1} \cap J_{2} \neq \varnothing$. Case (2) can be proved using similar arguments as in Lemma 2 because we can replace those subpaths with a new subpath of length at most 2 . For case (3), note that $a \leq b$ and $a^{\prime} \geq b^{\prime}, p$ and $q$ intersects in $\mathbb{R}^{2}$. Therefore, the intersection of $p$ and $q$ is in $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$, which implies $J_{1} \cap J_{2} \neq \varnothing$.
Definition 3. Let $J_{1}, J_{2} \subseteq(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ be connected and convex posets such that $J_{1} \cap J_{2}=\varnothing$. Given $M \in \operatorname{vect}_{k}^{\prime}$ such that $M(i \leq j)$ is an isomorphism for all $i \leq j \in J_{k}, k=1,2$, assume there exists $a_{0} \in J_{1}$ and $b_{0} \in J_{2}$ such that $a_{0} \leq b_{0}$. Then for any $a \in J_{1}$ and $b \in J_{2}$, define

$$
M(a \rightsquigarrow b)=M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a_{0} \leq b_{0}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}\right)
$$

where $a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}$ is a zigzag path in $J_{1}$ and $b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}$ is a zigzag path in $J_{2}$.
Proposition 5. $M(a \rightsquigarrow b)$ is well-defined. That is, $M(a \rightsquigarrow b)$ does not depend on the choice of $a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}$ and $b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}$. Moreover, if there exists $a_{0}^{\prime} \in J_{1}$ and $b_{0}^{\prime} \in J_{2}$ such that $a_{0}^{\prime} \leq b_{0}^{\prime}$, then $M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a_{0} \leq b_{0}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}\right)=M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a_{0}^{\prime} \leq b_{0}^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}^{\prime}\right)$.

We need the following lemmas to prove Proposition 5.
Lemma 5. Let $J \subseteq(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ be a connected and convex poset and $M \in \operatorname{vect}_{k}^{\prime}$ such that $M(i \leq j)$ is an isomorphism for all $i \leq j \in J$. Then for any $a \in(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ and $b, c \in J$ such that $a \leq b$ and $a \leq c$, then $M(b \rightsquigarrow c) \circ M(a \leq b)=M(a \leq c)$, where $b \rightsquigarrow c$ is any zigzag path in $J$ from $b$ to $c$.

Dually, for any $a \in(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ and $b, c \in J$ such that $a \geq b$ and $a \geq c$, then $M(c \leq$ a) $\circ M(b \rightsquigarrow c)=M(b \leq a)$, where $b \rightsquigarrow c$ is any zigzag path in $J$ from $b$ to $c$.

Proof. Let $p: b-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{n}-c$ be a zigzag path in $J$. Since $J$ is convex, we may assume $p$ is a reduced staircase. Induction on the length of $p$ (denoted by $l(p)$ ). When $l(p)=1, b$ and $c$ are comparable. Without loss of generality, we assume $b \leq c$. Note that $J$ is thin, hence $M(b \leq c) \circ M(a \leq b)=M(a \leq c)$.

When $l(p)=2$, there are 4 cases: (1) $b \leq x_{1} \leq c$; (2) $b \leq x_{1} \geq c$; (3) $b \geq x_{1} \leq c$; (4) $b \geq x_{1} \geq c$. Note that $p$ is a staircase in $J \subseteq(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ where both endpoints of $p$ is no smaller than $a$, hence $a \leq x_{1}$. Since $J$ is thin, we obtain $\bar{M}\left(b, x_{1}\right) \circ M(a \leq b)=$ $M\left(a \leq x_{1}\right)$ and $\bar{M}\left(x_{1}, c\right) \circ M\left(a \leq x_{1}\right)=M(a \leq c)$, which implies $M\left(b \stackrel{p}{\rightsquigarrow} c\right) \circ M(a \leq$ b) $=M(a \leq c)$.

Now we assume the statement is true when the length of any zigzag path (connecting $b$ and $c$ ) is no more than $N$. Let $p: b-x_{1}-x_{2}-\cdots-x_{N}-c$ be a zigzag path from $b$ to $c$ of length $N+1$. There are 3 cases: (1) $p$ has a self-intersection; (2) $p$ has no self-intersection but contains one of the following subpaths: BBG, GBB, BGG, or GGB; (3) $p$ has no self-intersection, and the arrows of $p$ alternate.

Cases (1) and (2) can be proved using similar arguments as in Lemma 2 because we can replace those subpaths with a new subpath of length at most 2 . For case (3), note that $a \leq b$ and $a \leq c$ in $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$, there exists $i \in\{1, \ldots, N\}$ such that $x_{i}$ is comparable to $a$. The induction hypothesis implies that $M\left(b \stackrel{p}{\rightsquigarrow} x_{i}\right) \circ M(a \leq b)=$

$M\left(a \leq x_{i}\right)$ and $M\left(x_{i} \xrightarrow{p} c\right) \circ M\left(a \leq x_{i}\right)=M(a \leq c)$. Therefore, $M\left(b \stackrel{p}{\sim} c\right) \circ M(a \leq b)=$ $M(a \leq c)$.

By induction, we conclude that $M\left(b \stackrel{p}{\sim} c\right) \circ M(a \leq b)=M(a \leq c)$ for all zigzag $p$ in $J$.
Lemma 6. Let $a, a^{\prime} \in J_{1}$ and $b, b^{\prime} \in J_{2}$ such that $a \leq b$ and $a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}$, where $J_{1}$ and $J_{2}$ are as defined above. Then $M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M(a \leq b)=M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)$.
Proof. Let $p: a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{n}-a^{\prime}$ be a zigzag path in $J_{1}$ and $q: b-y_{1}-\cdots-y_{m}-$ $b^{\prime}$ be a zigzag path in $J_{2}$. Since $J_{1}$ is convex, we may assume $p$ and $q$ are reduced staircases. Induction on the length of $p$. When $l(p)=0$, Lemma 5 implies that the statement is true. When $l(p)=1, a$ and $a^{\prime}$ are comparable. Without loss of generality, we assume $a \leq a^{\prime}$. Note that $a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}$, Lemma 5 implies that $M\left(a \leq b^{\prime}\right)=M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ$ $M(a \leq b)$ and $M\left(a \leq b^{\prime}\right)=M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)$. Therefore, the statement is true $l(p)=1$.

When $l(p)=2$, there are 4 cases: (1) $a \leq x_{1} \leq a^{\prime}$; (2) $a \leq x_{1} \geq a^{\prime}$; (3) $a \geq x_{1} \leq a^{\prime}$; (4) $a \geq x_{1} \geq a^{\prime}$. Note that $J_{1}$ is thin, Lemma 5 implies that the statement is true for cases (1), (3), and (4). For case (2), there are two subcases: (i) $x_{1}$ is comparable to $b$ or $b^{\prime}$ (ii) $x_{1}$ is not comparable to $b$ and $b^{\prime}$. For case (i), Since $J_{1} \cap J_{2}=\varnothing$, Lemma 4 implies $x_{1} \leq b$ or $x_{1} \leq b^{\prime}$. Without loss of generality, we assume $x_{1} \leq b$. Note that $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ is thin, hence $M(a \leq b)=M\left(x_{1} \leq b\right) \circ M\left(a \leq x_{1}\right)$. Note that $a^{\prime} \rightarrow x_{1}$ is a path of length 1 , therefore, $M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \leq b\right)=M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a^{\prime} \leq x_{1}\right)=M\left(a^{\prime} \leq\right.$ $\left.b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)$. For case (ii), note that there is no zigzag path in $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}-\uparrow x_{1}-\downarrow x_{1}$ connecting $b$ and $b^{\prime}$, where $\uparrow x_{1}$ is the principal upset at $x_{1}$ and $\downarrow x_{1}$ is the principal downset at $x_{1}$. Therefore, there exists $y \in\left\{b, b^{\prime}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{m}\right\}$ such that $x_{1} \leq y$ or $x_{1} \geq y$. Since $J_{1} \cap J_{2}=\varnothing$, Lemma 4 implies $x_{1} \leq y$. Since the length of path $a-x_{1}$ and $x_{1}-a^{\prime}$ is 1 , we obtain $M\left(x_{1} \leq y\right) \circ M\left(a \leq x_{1}\right)=M\left(b \rightsquigarrow y\right) \circ M(a \leq b)$ and $M\left(y \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \leq y\right)=M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a^{\prime} \leq x_{1}\right)^{-1}$. Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a^{\prime} \leq x_{1}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a \leq x_{1}\right) & =M\left(y \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \leq y\right) \circ M\left(a \leq x_{1}\right) \\
& =M\left(y \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(b \rightsquigarrow y\right) \circ M(a \leq b) \\
& =M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M(a \leq b)
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we assume the statement is true when the length of the zigzag path is less or equal to $N$. Let $p: a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{N}-a^{\prime}$ be a zigzag path in $J_{1}$. There are 3 cases: (1) $p$ has a self-intersection; (2) $p$ has no self-intersection but contains one of the following subpaths: BBG, GBB, BGG, or GGB; (3) $p$ has no self-intersection, and the arrows of $p$ alternate.

Cases (1) and (2) can be proved using similar arguments as in Lemma 2. For case (3), there are two subcases: (i) $x_{i}$ is comparable to $b$ or $b^{\prime}$ for some $i \in\{1, \ldots, N\}$ (ii) $x_{i}$ is not comparable to $b$ and $b^{\prime}$ for all $i \in\{1, \ldots, N\}$. For case (i), Since $J_{1} \cap J_{2}=\varnothing$, Lemma 4 implies $x_{i} \leq b$ or $x_{i} \leq b^{\prime}$. Without loss of generality, we assume $x_{i} \leq b$. Lemma 5 implies $M(a \leq b)=M\left(x_{1} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow x_{1}\right)$, and the induction hypothesis

implies $M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \leq b\right)=M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M(a \leq b) & =M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow x_{1}\right) \\
& =M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{1} \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow x_{1}\right) \\
& =M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

For case (ii), note that there is no zigzag path connecting $b$ and $b^{\prime}$ in $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}-\uparrow$ $x_{i}-\downarrow x_{i}$ for any $i \in\{1, \ldots, N\}$, there exists $y \in\left\{b, b^{\prime}, y_{1}, \ldots, y_{m}\right\}$ such that $x_{i} \leq y$ or $x_{i} \geq y$. Since $J_{1} \cap J_{2}=\varnothing$, Lemma 4 implies $x_{i} \leq y$. The induction hypothesis implies that $M(b \rightsquigarrow y) \circ M(a \leq b)=M\left(x_{i} \leq y\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow x_{i}\right)$ and $M\left(y \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{i} \leq y\right)=$ $M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{i} \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{aligned}
M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right) & =M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{i} \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow x_{i}\right) \\
& =M\left(y \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(x_{i} \leq y\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow x_{i}\right) \\
& =M\left(y \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M(b \rightsquigarrow y) \circ M(a \leq b) \\
& =M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M(a \leq b)
\end{aligned}
$$

By induction, we conclude that $M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M(a \leq b)=M\left(a^{\prime} \leq b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)$.

Proof of Proposition 5. Note that Lemma 3 implies that $M\left(a_{0} \rightsquigarrow a_{0}^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}\right)=$ $M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}^{\prime}\right)$ and $M\left(b_{0} \rightsquigarrow b_{0}^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}\right)=M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}^{\prime}\right)$. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
& M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a_{0}^{\prime} \leq b_{0}^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}^{\prime}\right) \\
& \quad=M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(b_{0} \rightsquigarrow b_{0}^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a_{0}^{\prime} \leq b_{0}^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a_{0} \rightsquigarrow a_{0}^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}\right) \\
& \quad=M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b_{0}\right)^{-1} \circ M\left(a_{0} \leq b_{0}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a_{0}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Theorem 1 is a direct consequence of Proposition 6.
Proposition 6. Let $M:(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2} \rightarrow$ vect $_{\mathbb{F}}$ be a persistence module. If there exists $a \in J_{1}$ and $b \in J_{2}$ such that $a \leq b$, then there exists a well-defined morphism $\phi_{J_{1} J_{2}}: \lim _{J_{1}} M \rightarrow \lim _{J_{2}} M$ such that the following diagram commutes:

where $\sigma_{i}$ is the leg map of the limit cone $\lim _{I_{1}} M \Rightarrow M \|_{I_{1}}$ and $\tau_{j}$ is the leg map of the limit cone $\lim _{I_{2}} M \Rightarrow M \|_{I_{2}}$.
Proof. We use the same construction as in Proposition 4, then both $\sigma_{i}$ and $\tau_{j}$ are isomorphisms for all $i \in J_{1}$ and $j \in J_{2}$ because they are compositions of isomorphisms. Define $\phi_{J_{1} J_{2}}=\tau_{b}^{-1} \circ M(i \leq j) \circ \sigma_{a}$. Now we will show $\phi_{J_{1} J_{2}}$ does not depend on the choice of $\sigma_{a}$ and $\tau_{b}$.

Let $\sigma_{a^{\prime}}: \lim _{I_{1}} M \rightarrow M a^{\prime}$ be the leg map of the limit cone and $\tau_{b^{\prime}}: \lim _{I_{2}} M \rightarrow M b^{\prime}$ be the leg map of the limit cone. Since $J_{1}$ is connected, there exists a zigzag path (denoted by $a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}$ ) from $a$ to $a^{\prime}$. Similarly, since $J_{2}$ is connected, there exists a zigzag path (denoted by $b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}$ ) from $b$ to $b^{\prime}$. Lemma 3 implies that $M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right) \circ \sigma_{a}=\sigma_{a}^{\prime}$ and $M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ \tau_{b}=\tau_{b}^{\prime}$.

Note that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\phi_{J_{1} J_{2}} & =\tau_{b}^{-1} \circ M(a \leq b) \circ \sigma_{a} \\
& =\tau_{b}^{\prime-1} \circ M\left(b \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M(a \leq b) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \circ \sigma_{a^{\prime}} \\
& =\tau_{b}^{\prime-1} \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow b^{\prime}\right) \circ M\left(a \rightsquigarrow a^{\prime}\right)^{-1} \circ \sigma_{a^{\prime}} \\

# 4 Finite Encodings of the 2-Parameter p.f.d. Persistence Modules with Finite Convex Isotopy Subdivisions 

Let $M \in \mathbf{v e c t}_{\mathbb{F}}^{\left(\mathbb{R}, \leq\right)^{2}}$. In this section, we show that there exists a finite encoding of $M$ if there exists a finite convex isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$.

Construct a set (denoted by $P$ ) and a homogeneous binary relation (denoted by $\rightarrow$ ) on $P$ as follows:

- Each chamber $J_{p}$ in $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ corresponds to an element $p \in P$;
- Given $p, q \in P . p \rightarrow q$ if
(1) $p=q$ or
(2) $p \neq q$, and there exists $x \in J_{p}$ and $y \in J_{q}$ such that $x \leq y$.

Lemma 7. $(P, \leq)$ is a poset, where $\leq$ is the transitive closure of $\rightarrow$.
Proof. We only need to show that $\rightarrow$ is antisymmetric. Assume $p \rightarrow q$ and $q \rightarrow p$, but $p \neq q$. Then $J_{p} \cap J_{q}=\varnothing$. If there exists $x, x^{\prime} \in J_{p}$ and $y, y^{\prime} \in J_{q}$ such that $x \leq y$ and $x^{\prime} \geq y^{\prime}$, Lemma 4 implies that $J_{p} \cap J_{q} \neq \varnothing$. Contradiction. Hence $p=q$.

Lemma 8. The construction of $(P, \leq)$ is functorial, i.e., the construction above gives a functor (denoted by $\mathcal{F}_{M}$ )

$$
\mathcal{F}_{M}:(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2} \rightarrow(P, \leq)
$$

Proof. At the object level, $\mathcal{F}_{M}$ sends $(x, y) \in(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ to $p \in P$, where $J_{p}$ is the chamber that contains $(x, y)$.

At the morphism level, $\mathcal{F}_{M}$ sends $(x, y) \rightarrow\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)$ to the unique morphism $p \rightarrow p^{\prime}$, where $J_{p}$ represents the chamber that contains $(x, y)$ and $J_{p}^{\prime}$ represents the chamber that contains $\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)$. Lemma 4 implies that $\mathcal{F}_{M}$ is well-defined because the chambers in $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ are convex, connected, and pairwise disjoint.

Note that when $p=p^{\prime},(x, y)$ and $\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)$ are in the same chamber. Without loss of generality, we assume $(x, y) \leq\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)$. Note that $\mathcal{F}_{M}$ sends $(x, y) \leq\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)$ to id ${ }_{p}$. Hence, in particular,

$$
\mathcal{F}_{M} \mathrm{id}_{(x, y)}=\mathrm{id}_{p}
$$

Since $(P, \leq)$ is thin, for all $(x, y),\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right),\left(x^{\prime \prime}, y^{\prime \prime}\right) \in(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ such that $(x, y) \leq$ $\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right) \leq\left(x^{\prime \prime}, y^{\prime \prime}\right)$,

$$
\mathcal{F}_{M}\left(\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right) \leq\left(x^{\prime \prime}, y^{\prime \prime}\right)\right) \circ \mathcal{F}_{M}\left((x, y) \leq\left(x^{\prime}, y^{\prime}\right)\right)=\mathcal{F}_{M}\left((x, y) \leq\left(x^{\prime \prime}, y^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)
$$

In conclusion, $\mathcal{F}_{M}$ is a functor.

Given $M \in \operatorname{vect}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$. Assume $M$ admits a finite convex isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ and let $(P, \leq)$ be the poset of chambers. Define $\bar{N}:(P, \leq) \rightarrow \operatorname{vect}_{\mathbb{F}}$ as follows:

- Given $p \in P, \bar{N}_{p}=\lim _{J_{p}} M \cong M i$ for all $i \in J_{p}$;
- For all $p \leq q \in P$,

$$
\bar{N}(p \leq q)= \begin{cases}\text { id }_{\lim _{J_{p}} M}, & \text { if } p=q \\ \phi_{J_{p} J_{q}}, & \text { else }\end{cases}
$$

where $\phi_{J_{p} J_{q}}$ is the canonical linear transformation defined in Proposition 6.
Proof of Theorem 2. Note that $\bar{N} \circ \mathcal{F}_{M}=N$, where $N$ is constructed in Theorem 1. Moreover, Theorem 1 implies $M \cong N$. Hence $M \cong \bar{N} \circ \mathcal{F}_{M}$.
Theorem 7. Let $M \in \operatorname{vect}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$. Assume there exists a finite convex isotopy subdivision of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ subordinate to $M$. Then $\mathcal{F}_{M}^{\prime}: \operatorname{vect}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(\mathbb{P}, \leq)} \rightarrow \operatorname{vect}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$ is fully-faithful, where $(P, \leq)$ is the poset of the chambers in $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$.
Proof. Let $\left\{J_{p} \mid p \in(P, \leq)\right\}$ be the set of chambers of the finite partition of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ that satisfyies the conditions of Theorem 1. Consider $\Phi: \operatorname{Hom}\left(N, N^{\prime}\right) \rightarrow \operatorname{Hom}(N \circ$ $\left.\mathcal{F}_{M}, N^{\prime} \circ \mathcal{F}_{M}\right)$ where $\left.\Phi\left(\left(\alpha_{p}\right)_{p \in(P, \leq)}\right)=\left(\beta_{i}\right)_{i \in(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}\right.$ and $\beta_{i}=\alpha_{p}$ when $i \in J_{p}$. It is clear that $\Phi$ is injective.

Let $\left(\beta_{i}\right)_{i \in(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}} \in \operatorname{Hom}\left(N \circ \mathcal{F}_{M}, N^{\prime} \circ \mathcal{F}_{M}\right)$. Given $p \in(P, \leq)$, the universal property of the limit implies that there exists a unique morphism $\alpha_{p}: \lim _{J_{p}} M \rightarrow \lim _{J_{p}} M^{\prime}$. Assume $p \leq q \in(P, \leq)$, the universal property of the limit implies that there exists a unique morphism $\lim _{J_{p}} M \rightarrow \lim _{J_{q}} M^{\prime}$. Hence $\left(\alpha_{p}\right)_{p \in(P, \leq)}$ is a morphism in $\operatorname{vect}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(P, \leq)}$. Therefore, $\Phi$ is surjective.

In conclusion, $\mathcal{F}_{M}^{\prime}$ is fully-faithful.

# 5 Thin Polycode Modules 

We have seen in Lemma 1 that polytope modules are thin and indecomposable. In this section, we will show that the converse of Lemma 1 is also true (up to isomorphism) when the indexing poset of the persistence module is $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$.
Lemma 9. Every indecomposable thin persistence module $M \in \operatorname{vect}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$ has connected support. Moreover, the support is a subposet of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$.
Proof. Let $P=\left(P_{0}, P_{1}\right)$ be the support ${ }^{3}$ of $M$. Define a binary relation $\leq$ on $P_{0}$ as follows: given $a, b \in P_{0}, a \leq b$ iff $a \leq b$ in $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ and $M(a \leq b) \neq 0$. Given $a \in P_{0}, M(a \leq a)=i \mathrm{id}_{M a}$. Moreover, given $a, b, c \in P_{0}$ where $M(a \leq b) \neq 0$ and $M(b \leq c) \neq 0$, note that $M(a \leq c)=M(a \leq b) \circ M(b \leq c) \neq 0$ because $M$ is a thin

representation. Therefore, $\leq$ is a partial order on $P_{0}$. We denote this poset $P_{0}$ with the partial order $\leq$ as $(P, \leq)$. It is clear that $(P, \leq)$ is a subposet of $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$.

We now claim that $(P, \leq)$ is connected: Assume $(P, \leq)$ is not connected, then there exists $a, b \in P$ such that there is no zigzag path connecting $a$ and $b$. Define

S=\{x \in P: x \text { and } a \text { is joined by a zigzag path in }(P, \leq)\}

and $T=S^{c}$. Define $N, N^{\prime}:(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2} \rightarrow$ vect $_{\mathbb{R}}$ by

$$
N i= \begin{cases}M i, & \text { if } i \in S \\ 0, & \text { else }\end{cases}, \quad N(i \leq j)= \begin{cases}M(i \leq j), & \text { if } i \leq j \in S \\ 0, & \text { else }\end{cases}
$$

and

$$
N^{\prime} i= \begin{cases}M i, & \text { if } i \in T \\ 0, & \text { else }\end{cases}, \quad N^{\prime}(i \leq j)= \begin{cases}M(i \leq j), & \text { if } i \leq j \in T \\ 0, & \text { else }\end{cases}
$$

It is clear that $M \cong N \oplus N^{\prime}$, and both $N$ and $N^{\prime}$ are not trivial since $N a \neq 0$ and $N^{\prime} b \neq 0$. Contradiction. Therefore, $(P, \leq)$ is connected.

Lemma 10. Let $M \in \mathbf{V e c t}_{\mathbb{R}}^{(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}}$ be a thin persistence module and let $(P, \leq)$ be the support of $M$. Then for any $a, b \in P$ such that $a<b, M(a<b): M a \rightarrow M b$ is not 0 if there exists a zigzag path from a to $b$ in $(P, \leq)$.
Proof. Since $(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ is a thin category, we can assume such a zigzag path in $(P, \leq)$ consists of horizontal and vertical arrows. We say an arrow on the zigzag path is a good arrow if the orientation of the arrow coincides with the orientation of the zigzag path; otherwise, we say the arrow is a bad arrow. WLOG, we may assume all zigzag paths are reduced: the zigzag path doesn't have two (or more) consecutive horizontal or vertical arrows, i.e., we either

- combine the two (or more) consecutive horizontal or vertical arrows if they are all good arrows or all bad arrows;
- get a new (shorter) arrow from combining a good horizontal (vertical, resp) arrow with a bad horizontal (vertical, resp) arrow.
- The new arrow is good if the length of the original good arrow is strictly greater than the length of the original bad arrow;
- The new arrow is bad if the length of the original good arrow is strictly less than the length of the original bad arrow;
- The new arrow is a vertex if the length of the original good arrow is equal to the length of the original bad arrow.
Induction on the length of the zigzag path.
- length $=1$. There is nothing to show.
- length $=N \rightarrow N+1$.

- If the zigzag path has at least one self-intersection (denote a self-intersection by c) then we can write the zigzag path as follows

$$
a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{m}-c-y_{1}-\cdots-y_{n}-c-z_{1}-\cdots z_{N-m-n-2}-b
$$

where $n \geq 1$. (Note that the induction hypothesis strikes when $c=a$ or $c=b$.) Therefore,

$$
a-x_{1}-\cdots-x_{m}-c-z_{1}-\cdots z_{N-m-n-2}-b
$$

is a zigzag path from $a$ to $b$ with a maximum length of $N$. By induction hypothesis, $M(a<b) \neq 0$.

- Now we assume the zigzag path has no self-intersection.
- If the zigzag path consists of good arrows, then $M(a<b) \neq 0$;
- If we have a bad (B) arrow on the zigzag path, then
- there exist two consecutive good (G) arrows adjacent to the bad (B) arrow, i.e., BGG or GGB; or
- there exist two consecutive bad (B) arrows adjacent to the good (G) arrow, i.e., GBB or BBG

Otherwise,
the zigzag path consists of bad arrows;
or
good arrow and bad arrow alternate on the zigzag path.
contradicting the assumption that $a<b$.
Because $\left(\mathbb{R}^{2}, \leq\right)$ is thin, we can substitute BBG/GBB/GGB/BGG with two new arrows (maybe degenerate). Therefore, the length of the new zigzag path is at most $N$. By the induction hypothesis, $M(a<b) \neq 0$.
In conclusion, if there exists a zigzag path from $a<b$ in $(P, \leq)$, then $M(a<b) \neq$ 0 .

Proof of Theorem3. Let $(P, \leq)$ be the support of $M$. Lemma 9 implies that $(P, \leq)$ is connected. Moreover, Lemma 10 implies that $(P, \leq)$ is convex: otherwise, there exists $a \leq c \leq b \in(\mathbb{R}, \leq)^{2}$ such that $a, b \in P$ and $c \notin P$. Hence $M(a \leq b)=M(c \leq$ b) $\circ M(a \leq c)=0$ because $M c=0$. Contradiction. Hence $(P, \leq)$ is convex.

Now we construct the morphism between $M$ and $\mathbb{F} P$. Fix $a \in P$, define $\alpha: M \Rightarrow$ $\mathbb{F} P$ as follows: for all $b \in P$ and $x \in M b$,

$$
\alpha_{b}(x)= \begin{cases}M(a \rightsquigarrow b) x, & \text { if } b \in P \\ 0, & \text { else }\end{cases}
$$

Lemma 3 ensures $\alpha_{b}$ is well-defined. It is clear that $\alpha$ is a natural transformation, and it is a natural isomorphism because $\alpha_{b}$ is invertible for all $b \in P$, where

$$
\alpha_{b}^{-1}(x)=M(b \rightsquigarrow a) x=M(a \rightsquigarrow b)^{-1} x
$$

The following example shows that both Theorem 2 and Theorem 3 may fail when a persistence module has more than two parameters.
Example 3. Define $Q=\{(x, y, z) \in\{0,1\}^{3} \mid 1 \leq x+y+z \leq 2\} \subseteq \mathbb{Z}^{3}$. Equip $Q$ with the partial order induced by the product order on $(\mathbb{Z}, \leq)^{3}$. Given $m \in \mathbb{R}-\{0\}$, consider a thin persistence module $M:(\mathbb{Z}, \leq)^{3} \rightarrow$ vect $_{\mathbb{F}}$ where $M i= \begin{cases}\mathbb{F}, & \text { if } i \in Q \\ 0, & \text { else }\end{cases}$ and $M(i \leq j)(x)= \begin{cases}0, & \text { if } i \notin Q \text { or } j \notin Q \\ m x, & \text { if } i=(0,1,0) \text { and } j=(1,1,0) . \text { It is clear that } M \text { is thin and } \\ x, & \text { else }\end{cases}$ indecomposable for all $m \neq 0$, and $M$ is isomorphic to the polytope module $\mathbb{F} Q$ if and only if $m=1$.

Since $M i \cong M j$ for all $i, j \in Q$ and $Q$ is connected, $M$ has only one (non-trivial) chamber. Therefore, the poset of chambers $(P, \leq)$ is a singleton set. Fix $m \neq 1$. Assume there exists $N \in \operatorname{vect}_{\mathbb{F}}^{(P, \leq)}$ such that $M \cong N \circ \mathcal{F}_{M}$. Note that $N p=\mathbb{F}$ for all $p \in P$ and $P=\{p\}$; therefore, $M$ is isomorphic to the polytope module $\mathbb{F} Q$, which is a contradiction.

abstract:
In this paper, we study pointwise finite-dimensional (p.f.d.) $2$-parameter
persistence modules where each module admits a finite convex isotopy
subdivision. We show that a p.f.d. $2$-parameter persistence module $M$ (with a
finite convex isotopy subdivision) is isomorphic to a $2$-parameter persistence
module $N$ where the restriction of $N$ to each chamber of the parameter space
$(\mathbb{R},\leq)^2$ is a constant functor. Moreover, we show that the convex
isotopy subdivision of $M$ induces a finite encoding of $M$. Finally, we prove
that every indecomposable thin $2$-parameter persistence module is isomorphic
to a polytope module.
